hint.text:
• The integer 1 is the identity under multiplication, i.e.,\( 1 \times p = p \times 1 = p\) for any integer p.
  • When a positive integer is divided by a negative integer, the quotient obtained is a negative integer and vice-versa.
  • Division of a negative integer by another negative integer gives a positive integer as quotient.
  • Integer 0 is the identity under addition. That is,\( p + 0 = 0 + p = p \)for every integer p.
  • Multiplication is commutative for integers. That is,\( p \times q = q \times p\) for any integers p and q.
  • Addition is commutative for integers, i.e., \(p + q = q + p\) for all integers p and q.
  • Addition is associative for integers, i.e.,\( (p + q) + r = p + (q + r)\) for all integers p, q and r.
  • Subtraction is neither commutative nor associative for integers.
  • \( p \div 1 = p, p \times 0 = 0\).
